vulnerability_findings.name: Exception State (SWC 110)
vulnerability_findings.message:
An assertion violation was triggered.
It is possible to trigger an assertion violation. Note that Solidity assert() statements should only be used to check invariants. Review the transaction trace generated for this issue and either make sure your program logic is correct, or use require() instead of assert() if your goal is to constrain user inputs or enforce preconditions. Remember to validate inputs from both callers (for instance, via passed arguments) and callees (for instance, via return values).
Classification: SWC-110

vulnerability_findings.name: Integer Arithmetic Bugs (SWC 101)
vulnerability_findings.message:
The arithmetic operator can overflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation. 
Classification: SWC-101

vulnerability_findings.name: Exception State (SWC 110)
vulnerability_findings.message:
An assertion violation was triggered.
It is possible to trigger an assertion violation. Note that Solidity assert() statements should only be used to check invariants. Review the transaction trace generated for this issue and either make sure your program logic is correct, or use require() instead of assert() if your goal is to constrain user inputs or enforce preconditions. Remember to validate inputs from both callers (for instance, via passed arguments) and callees (for instance, via return values).
Classification: SWC-110

vulnerability_findings.name: Dependence on predictable environment variable (SWC 120)
vulnerability_findings.message:
A control flow decision is made based on The block hash of a previous block.
The block hash of a previous block is used to determine a control flow decision. Note that the values of variables like coinbase, gaslimit, block number and timestamp are predictable and can be manipulated by a malicious miner. Also keep in mind that attackers know hashes of earlier blocks. Don't use any of those environment variables as sources of randomness and be aware that use of these variables introduces a certain level of trust into miners.
Classification: SWC-120

vulnerability_findings.name: incorrect-equality
vulnerability_findings.message:
DrainMe.unlockSecret (patch_8.sol#64-73) uses a dangerous strict equality:
	- secret % 5 == 0

vulnerability_findings.name: shadowing-local
vulnerability_findings.message:
DrainMe.unlockSecret.secret (local variable @ patch_8.sol#66) shadows:
	- DrainMe.secret (state variable @ patch_8.sol#12)

vulnerability_findings.name: constable-states
vulnerability_findings.message:
DrainMe.firstTarget should be constant (patch_8.sol#6)
DrainMe.secondTarget should be constant (patch_8.sol#7)
